title: Pancreatitis Recovery: Helping Your Dog Heal at Home

steps.title: Offer your dog low-fat, frequent meals.
steps.content: Offer your dog low-fat, frequent meals. Pancreatitis is often caused by a long-term diet of high-fat dog food. [1] X Research source As your dog recovers, they may have less of an appetite than usual. Try tempting them with low-fat foods 4 to 5 times per day for several weeks. steps.title: Use anti-nausea medication to settle your dog’s stomach.
steps.content: Use anti-nausea medication to settle your dog’s stomach. Your vet may send you home with anti-nausea medicine for your pup, since pancreatitis can make them feel a bit queasy. Follow the recommended dosage from your vet to help soothe your dog’s discomfort and get them to eat. [3] X Research source If your dog is still throwing up, hold off on offering them food, and instead, give them access to lots of fresh water.

steps.title: Give your dog pain medication if your vet prescribes it.
steps.content: Give your dog pain medication if your vet prescribes it. Pancreatitis can be painful, especially in severe cases. Your vet may give you pain medication to take home with you. [4] X Research source If that’s the case, follow the recommended dosage for your dog to soothe them and make them feel more at ease.

steps.title: Cuddle your dog and give them extra love.
steps.content: Cuddle your dog and give them extra love. When dogs are sick, they often want to be closer to their humans than ever before. Stay near your dog, and offer them lots of cuddles and pets to comfort your sick pup . [5] X Research source Some dogs may not want to cuddle while they’re sick, and that’s okay. Pay attention to your dog’s body language: if they’re baring their teeth, growling, or trying to get away from you, they probably just want some alone time instead. As your dog recovers, avoid straining them by taking them on short walks instead of doing strenuous exercise.

steps.title: Pancreatitis is the inflammation of the pancreas.
steps.content: Pancreatitis is the inflammation of the pancreas. The pancreas produces digestive enzymes to break down your pet’s food. When it becomes inflamed, it can cause a lot of digestive issues and discomfort. [6] X Research source If left untreated, pancreatitis can lead to dehydration, diabetes, or organ damage. In severe cases, it can become life-threatening.

steps.title: Loss of appetite
steps.content: Loss of appetite Since the pancreas is an integral part of digestion, an inflamed pancreas means your pup won’t be as hungry as they usually are. You might notice that they stop eating their kibble or refuse the treats that you give them. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Vomiting or diarrhea
steps.content: Vomiting or diarrhea One of the primary ways you can spot signs of pancreatitis in dogs is by seeing if their stomach is upset. While occasional gastrointestinal distress is normal, if your dog is throwing up or having diarrhea for multiple days, it could be a sign of pancreatitis. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Abdominal pain and swelling
steps.content: Abdominal pain and swelling A swollen pancreas is painful, and your pup might act lethargic or like they’re in discomfort. You might also notice swelling in your dog’s abdomen and stomach area. [9] X Research source When dogs have abdominal pain, they will often go into the “prayer position,” where their front legs are on the ground but their back legs are in the air. This is a sure sign that something is wrong and that your dog is in pain.

steps.title: Dehydration
steps.content: Dehydration Your dog may not be drinking enough fluids because they’re in pain, which can lead to severe dehydration. steps.title: High-fat diet
steps.content: High-fat diet The most common cause of pancreatitis is a high-fat diet over multiple years. [11] X Research source If your dog eats dog food that has more than 20% fat in it, it can put stress on the pancreas, leading to pancreatitis.

steps.title: Dietary indiscretion
steps.content: Dietary indiscretion “Dietary indiscretion” is the medical terminology for when your dog eats anything. Studies have shown that dogs who eat garbage, human food, or dirt are more likely to develop pancreatitis. [12] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source

steps.title: Obesity
steps.content: Obesity When your dog is overweight, it puts a strain on all of their organs, including the pancreas. If they have been overweight for a while, they could develop pancreatitis as a result of that. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Most dogs recover from mild cases in 2 to 4 days.
steps.content: Most dogs recover from mild cases in 2 to 4 days. The prognosis of pancreatitis really depends on how severe it is. The good news is that if it’s caught and treated quickly, your dog will likely recover and be back to normal in just a few days. If they have a severe case of pancreatitis, your vet may recommend a stay at the vet or long-term care measures. [14] X Research source Pancreatitis can recur after it’s happened once. To avoid it in the future, keep your pup on a low-fat diet and don’t let them eat unusual foods.
